awd_titl_txt: Seismic Anisotropy across the USArray using Surface-wave Arrival Angles
awd_abstract_narration:
The deployment of the USArray transportable array (TA) has allowed seismologists to compile seismic datasets and images with unprecedented detail. Seismic analyses of an extremely rich dataset of some 2000 stations have so far been based on 'standard' seismic data such as travel times. However, other kinds of data such as the particle motion of surface waves provide complementary observations to model smaller details in shallow Earth structure. The short distance between TA stations allows seismologists to trace in detail how surface waves from distant earthquakes bend around as they traverse the TA. This, in turn, can be used to fine-tune models of Earth structure beneath North America and improve scientists' understanding how the continent is made up.
Certain mantle rocks exhibit seismic anisotropy where the speed at which seismic waves travel depend on the direction from which they approach. Anisotropy also forms when a plate, such as the North American plate, responds to forces tugging along its edges. Small subsets of TA stations can be used like antennas to measure the properties of this anisotropy. This, in turn, allows scientists to explore mantle processes that form, move and ultimately destroy Earth's plates. 
This project will collect both types of data.


In global tomographic studies, surface-wave arrival angles have proven extremely useful to enhance the imaging of short-wavelength structure. Due to the sparseness of the global seismic networks the interpretation of such data were interpreted using perturbation theory to a great-circle approach. The dense USArray Transportable Array (TA) allows seismologists to observe the structure-induced evolution of the teleseismic wavefield across a large network in unprecedented detail. While Helmholtz tomography utilizes the amplitude and phase of one-component surface wave waveforms, the evolution of surface wave particle motion provides complementary constraints on small-scale heterogeneity beneath North America.  While arrival angles support phase-based dispersion analyses of the mantle, observables such as the dip and the ZH ratio are particularly useful to constrain shallow crustal layers. This project will provide a new database of surface-wave particle motion observable.
A second aspect of this project focuses on Rayleigh wave azimuthal anisotropy. The dense station spacing of the TA allows a leap-frogging "beam forming" type approach using small subarrays. In comparison to an all-inclusive tomographic joint inversion scheme for anisotropy and heterogeneity, this approach can remove some of the trade-offs between the two. The underlying assumption here is that structure within a subarray is homogeneous, but given the dense station spacing of the TA, this should be a valid assumption. In return, obtained observables will be "in-situ".

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the assembly of a database of secondary surface wave observables to ultimately enhance tomographic imaging of the seismic structure beneath the contiguous United States. After the completion of the deployment of the USArray Transportable Array (TA) from 2004 through 2013, several publications by others described the analysis of primary surface wave observables, namely the frequency-dependent phase and group arrival times. This study focused on the measurement of arrival angles that are the result of diversion of waves from the source-receiver great circle as a result of lateral variations in structure. As previously demonstrated
arrival angles enhance the imaging of fine-scale structure, compared to using only travel times. In addition, it was shown that these angles can be measured to an accuracy sufficient enough to be statistically significant. The principal investigator has extensive experience measuring arrival angles interactively 'by hand'. This project provided the opportunity to experiment with automated algorithms.

This project also provided an opportunity to collect in-situ measurements of azimuthal anisotropy. Here, the researchers focused on the measurement of Rayleigh wave phase velocity as function of azimuth. In the presence of stresses acting on a tectonic plate, ancient and current flow in Earth's mantle, seismic velocities can become anisotropic. The new collection of azimuthal anisotropy data therefore allows researchers to make inferences on mantle flow beneath the U.S., and ultimately understand how plate tectonics works under the
entire continent. This part of the project is still ongoing, and publications will follow upon completion.

Broader impacts: Several graduate students on this project worked on different aspects of the proposed research. All of them engaged in the measurement of surface wave arrival angles and received training in theoretical, observational and numerical aspects of surface wave research. This grant supported three UCSD undergraduate student employees who were trained in the
hands-on measurement of surface wave particle motion. One of the three subsequently enrolled in an independent
studies project to present his work on a poster for the SIO undergraduate student research symposium. This
poster received a best presentation award. The research for this project has been published in the high-impact journal Seismological Research Letters, and several more publications will follow shortly. The principal investigator engages in numerous public education and outreach events, most recently through interviews for the New York Times and Turkish radio and a public lecture to the San Diego Saturday Desert Society. The research team has also participated in education and outreach events with the Birch Aquarium at Scripps to entice all children, but particularly girls, to consider a STEM college education and career.
